Hi Julian, I have a few comments on some of the stuff you brought 
up...

-=
-- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Julian Togelius <julian@t...> wrote:
> >  I rea=
lized that I never asked Julian specifically if they focus 
on
> >  TWEANN =
approaches to NE, but judging by the work that he, 
personally,
> >  has do=
ne, it would appear so.  Regardless, I'll soon find out.
> >  
> 
> Many of=
 the more important people there seem to have a penchant for
> small, fully=
 connected, continuous networks, such as CTRNNs and
> spiking models. I mys=
elf think that having a network fully 
connected
> can be disastrous to evo=
lvability, as a change in any connection 
will
> affect every neuron in the=
 network. Epistasis is the word. What is
> interesting about CTRNNs and sim=
ilar nets is that every neuron has
> state and decay properties, which can =
be used for some interesting
> integration of information over time. The te=
nd to be quite
> computationally expensive, though, and I go with much simp=
ler 
neuron
> models for my current experiments with very large networks.
>=
 

Some interesting things about CTRNNs:  It's worth pointing out that 
the=
y don't need to be fully-connected and they are really quite cool 
in my op=
inion.  In fact, NEAT can evolve CTRNNs, although this 
possibility has not=
 been thoroughly investigated.  But I think it's 
fascinating since CTRNNs =
can act as internal pattern generators, 
which means they can produce thing=
s like regular gaits or swimming 
motions.

In fact, Tyler Streeter actuall=
y produced a CTRNN version of NEAT a 
while ago.  Tyler's since moved on to=
 experimenting with other 
methods (such as temporal difference RL learning=
) but his July 2004 
videos in his gallery are actually taken from a NEAT-e=
volved CTRNN 
network:

http://www.vrac.iastate.edu/~streeter/verve/gallery=
.html

Someday I'd like to get serious about learning about evolving the 
t=
opology and temoral dynamics of CTRNNs and the kinds of complex 
pattern ge=
nerators that might be possible.

> Having said that, several of the people=
 there have done forays into
> artificial embryogeny, and Gruau (of Cellula=
r Encoding fame) was 
there
> for a while. And you are very much free to do=
 whatever you want in 
the
> EASy programme - they probably wouldn't object=
 too much if you 
handed
> in an oil painting or something you built out of=
 matchsticks and
> crumbled bread instead of an essay... (Well, they might =
not be that
> liberal, but almost.)
> 
> >  Examining the Universities in B=
ritish Columbia (EA 
headquarters), I
> >  see a lot of AI possibilities bu=
t nothing that mentions 
anything close
> >  to NE.  Shame.
> 
> J=F6rg Den=
zinger works with EA on evolutionary approaches
(unintended
> acronym pun t=
here) to finding "sweet spots" in games amongst other
> things - interestin=
g research. I don't know how much he is into 
neural
> networks, though. Th=
e work I've seen by him is on evolving action
> sequences.
> 
> http://page=
s.cpsc.ucalgary.ca/~denzinge/
> 

Julian, do you remember seeing J=F6rg at =
the CIG conference in
April?  
He gave a couple talks there about this work=
.

ken
